Literature Review: Between-plant signaling is an emerging field of study that has gained significant attention in recent years due to its potential implications for plant ecology, evolution, and agriculture. This review focuses on two primary mechanisms of between-plant signaling: parasitic plants and common mycelial networks (CMNs) formed by mycorrhizal fungi.Parasitic plants have evolved specialized organs called haustoria, which allow them to establish intimate connections with their host plants. These connections enable the transfer of various biomolecules and signals between the parasite and host, and even among different hosts connected by the same parasite. Westwood et al. (2010) provided a comprehensive overview of the haustorium structure and function, highlighting its role in nutrient acquisition and signal exchange. The haustorium-host interface serves as a conduit for the transfer of water, nutrients, secondary metabolites, messenger RNAs, noncoding RNAs, proteins, and systemic signals.Recent studies have revealed the complexity of molecular exchanges occurring through haustoria. Kim et al. (2014) demonstrated the bidirectional movement of mRNAs between the parasitic plant Cuscuta pentagona and its hosts, suggesting a novel mechanism for genetic information exchange. This finding has profound implications for our understanding of plant-plant interactions and the potential for horizontal gene transfer in nature.The transfer of small RNAs through haustorial connections has also been documented. Shahid et al. (2018) showed that Cuscuta campestris, a parasitic plant, sends microRNAs into its host plants to suppress host defense genes, facilitating successful parasitism. This discovery highlights the sophisticated strategies employed by parasitic plants to manipulate their hosts at the molecular level.In addition to nucleic acids, proteins have been found to move between parasitic plants and their hosts. Aly et al. (2011) identified numerous host proteins present in the parasitic plant Phelipanche aegyptiaca, providing evidence for large-scale protein trafficking across species boundaries. This protein movement may have significant consequences for host-parasite interactions and could potentially influence the physiology of both organisms.Parallel to the parasitic plant system, mycorrhizal fungi form extensive underground networks known as common mycelial networks (CMNs), which can connect multiple plants simultaneously. These networks have been shown to facilitate the transfer of various compounds and signals between plants. Simard et al. (1997) provided early evidence for the transfer of carbon between trees through mycorrhizal networks, challenging our understanding of forest ecology and plant community dynamics.Subsequent research has expanded our knowledge of the types of signals that can be transmitted through CMNs. Song et al. (2010) demonstrated that tomato plants connected by mycorrhizal networks could transfer defense signals to neighboring plants, enhancing their resistance to foliar diseases. This finding suggests that CMNs may play a crucial role in plant-plant communication and community-level responses to biotic stresses.The potential for CMNs to mediate abiotic stress responses has also been explored. Babikova et al. (2013) showed that aphid-infested broad bean plants could warn neighboring plants of impending attack through mycorrhizal networks, leading to increased production of volatile organic compounds in the receiving plants. This study highlights the ecological significance of CMN-mediated signaling in plant defense against herbivores.Recent research has begun to unravel the molecular mechanisms underlying signal transmission through CMNs. Kaiser et al. (2015) identified specific fungal genes involved in the transfer of nitrogen between plants connected by ectomycorrhizal networks, providing insights into the genetic basis of nutrient exchange in these systems.The implications of between-plant signaling extend beyond individual plant interactions to ecosystem-level processes. Gorzelak et al. (2015) reviewed the potential impacts of mycorrhizal networks on forest resilience and regeneration, suggesting that these underground connections may play a crucial role in maintaining ecosystem stability and adaptation to environmental changes.As our understanding of between-plant signaling continues to grow, it becomes increasingly clear that plants are not isolated entities but rather interconnected members of complex communities. The ability of plants to exchange information and resources through parasitic connections and mycorrhizal networks has profound implications for plant ecology, evolution, and agriculture. Future research in this field will likely focus on elucidating the full range of signals that can be transmitted between plants, the mechanisms governing these transfers, and the ecological consequences of these interactions at various scales.
